title: Vectorized Sparse Encoding
text: several types VSEs, categorized follows: CSC: Colum Sparse Compressed base structure, records non-zero value/index information form another. P: type polymorphic, meaning indices values can different types. NP: type non-polymorphic, meaning indices values must type (usually integral) T: Tabulated, meaning unique value given , precedes indices value occurs. R: Run, tabulated storage, value immediately followed run size (number indices value) followed indices value occurs. following VSEs implemented package: CSC (vectorized), CSC_P, CSC_NP, TCSC_P, TCSC_NP, TRCSC_NP.

title: Vectorized Sparse Encoding
text: VSEs coded C++ std::vector std::pair using two template types, value type (val_t) index type (idx_t). simulate small random matrix inspect. C++ structure easily appreciated R debug, VSE::inspect function allows us gain idea encoding looks like using R lists.

title: Vectorized Sparse Encoding
text: Stored std::vector<idx_t> std::vector<idx_t> x. Two vectors, thus fully vectorized, requiring joint traversal iteration.

title: Vectorized Sparse Encoding
text: Stored std::vector<std::pair<idx_t, val_t>> permitting polymorphism (val_t idx_t necessarily type) also enforcing contiguous vectorization.
code: inspect(A, "CSC_P") #> List of 2 #>  $ :List of 8 #>   ..$ : int 0 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 2 #>   .. ..$ value: int 3 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 4 #>   .. ..$ value: int 3 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 13 #>   .. ..$ value: int 1 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 14 #>   .. ..$ value: int 1 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 24 #>   .. ..$ value: int 3 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 25 #>   .. ..$ value: int 2 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 26 #>   .. ..$ value: int 1 #>  $ :List of 9 #>   ..$ : int 0 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 0 #>   .. ..$ value: int 1 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 6 #>   .. ..$ value: int 1 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 11 #>   .. ..$ value: int 2 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 12 #>   .. ..$ value: int 2 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 17 #>   .. ..$ value: int 3 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 19 #>   .. ..$ value: int 3 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 20 #>   .. ..$ value: int 1 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 26 #>   .. ..$ value: int 2

title: Vectorized Sparse Encoding
text: Stored std::vector<idx_t> values must type index type, necessarily integral. can include signed unsigned types.

title: Vectorized Sparse Encoding
text: Stored std::vector<std::pair<val_t, std::vector<idx_t>>>, structure permits tabulated encoding polymorphic types. particularly inefficient terms memory storage iterator traversal, possibly preferable values discrete non-integral, extremely redundant.
code: inspect(A, "TCSC_P") #> List of 2 #>  $ :List of 3 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ value: int 3 #>   .. ..$ index: num [1:3] 2 4 24 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ value: int 1 #>   .. ..$ index: num [1:3] 13 14 26 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ value: int 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num 25 #>  $ :List of 3 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ value: int 1 #>   .. ..$ index: num [1:3] 0 6 20 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ value: int 2 #>   .. ..$ index: num [1:3] 11 12 26 #>   ..$ :List of 2 #>   .. ..$ value: int 3 #>   .. ..$ index: num [1:2] 17 19

title: Vectorized Sparse Encoding
text: Stored std::vector<idx_t> idx_t must signed values must positive integral. Values denoted negative sign, indices positive sign. Values listed followed indices occur.

title: Vectorized Sparse Encoding
text: Stored std::vector<idx_t> idx_t may signed (permit signed values) unsigned. Values listed, followed number indices occur, followed indices value.

title: Vectorized Sparse Encoding
text: Since VSEs column vectors, sparse matrix computations can done column-wise column-major format. VSEs also rely sparse random access iterators, case CSC_P, CSC_NP ordered row index, cases T formats ordered firstly value secondarily row index. means sparse-sparse operations T formats extremely inefficient, thus T formats use sparse-dense operations.

title: Vectorized Sparse Encoding
text: Since iterators workhorse VSEs, two proof--concept applications iterators implemented. First, compute sum VSE can computed traversing container interest values, indices. Second, compute sparse-dense cross-product operation traversing container using random access iterator dense matrix. former challenges efficient traversal structure, second challenges ordered vs.Â unordered access row indices. generate matrix 90% redundancy: matrix 95% redundancy: Now can compute runtimes matrix using compression method:    matrix 95% redundant:
code: A <- rsparsematrix(1000, 100, 0.1, rand.x = function(n) sample(1:9, n, replace = TRUE)) mean(calc_redundancy(A)) #> [1] 0.8992035 A2 <- rsparsematrix(1000, 100, 0.1, rand.x = function(n) sample(1:4, n, replace = TRUE)) mean(calc_redundancy(A2)) #> [1] 0.9495477 h <- matrix(runif(10 * 100), 10, 100) benchmark(A, h) #> constructing CSC #> constructing CSC_P #> constructing CSC_NP #> constructing TCSC_P #> constructing TCSC_NP #> constructing RTCSC_NP p1 <- plot(bench_colsums) p2 <- plot(bench_tcrossprod) library(cowplot) library(ggplot2) cowplot::plot_grid(p1 + ggtitle("colsums"), p2 + ggtitle("tcrossprod"), nrow = 1) benchmark(A2, h) #> constructing CSC #> constructing CSC_P #> constructing CSC_NP #> constructing TCSC_P #> constructing TCSC_NP #> constructing RTCSC_NP p1 <- plot(bench_colsums) p2 <- plot(bench_tcrossprod) cowplot::plot_grid(p1 + ggtitle("colsums"), p2 + ggtitle("tcrossprod"), nrow = 1)

title: Vectorized Sparse Encoding
text: Calculate compression object using memuse: Now plot results learn efficient data structures function sparsity redundancy:  function sparsity (holding redundancy constant possible):  Compare memory usage R dgCMatrix, assuming indices values dgCMatrix can held short int:
code: encodings <- c("CSC", "CSC_P", "CSC_NP", "TCSC_P", "TCSC_NP", "TRCSC_NP")  df <- list() for(i in 2:20){   for(sparsity in seq(0.01, 0.2, 0.01)){     A <- rsparsematrix(1000, 100, sparsity, rand.x = function(n) sample(1:i, n, replace = TRUE))     redundancy <- calc_redundancy(A)     df[[length(df) + 1]] <- data.frame(       "encoding" = encodings,        "size" = sapply(encodings, function(encoding) memuse(A, encoding)),        "redundancy" = mean(redundancy),        "sparsity" = length(A@x) / prod(dim(A)))   } } df <- do.call(rbind, df) head(df) #>          encoding  size redundancy sparsity #> CSC           CSC  8800   0.657156     0.01 #> CSC_P       CSC_P  8000   0.657156     0.01 #> CSC_NP     CSC_NP  6400   0.657156     0.01 #> TCSC_P     TCSC_P 15652   0.657156     0.01 #> TCSC_NP   TCSC_NP  4788   0.657156     0.01 #> TRCSC_NP TRCSC_NP  5176   0.657156     0.01 ggplot(subset(df, sparsity == 0.05),         aes(redundancy, size, color = encoding)) +   theme_classic() +    theme(aspect.ratio = 1) +    geom_line() + scale_y_continuous(trans = "log10") +    labs(title = "sparsity = 0.05") +    theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) ggplot(subset(df, redundancy >= 0.85 & redundancy <= 0.88),         aes(sparsity, size, color = encoding)) +    theme_classic() +    theme(aspect.ratio = 1) +    geom_jitter(height = 0, widht = 0.1) +    scale_y_continuous(trans = "log10") +    labs(title = "redundancy in the range (0.85, 0.88)") +    theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) +    geom_smooth() #> Warning: Ignoring unknown parameters: widht #> `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula 'y ~ x' A <- rsparsematrix(10000, 100, 0.05, rand.x = function(n) sample(1:5, n, replace = TRUE)) redundancy <- round(mean(calc_redundancy(A)), 2) df <- data.frame("encoding" = encodings, "bytes" = sapply(encodings, function(encoding) memuse(A, encoding))) df <- rbind(df, data.frame("encoding" = "dgCMatrix", "bytes" = as.numeric(object.size(A)))) ggplot(df, aes(reorder(encoding, -bytes), bytes)) +    geom_bar(stat = "identity") +    theme_classic() +    theme(aspect.ratio = 1) +    labs(     y = "object size (bytes)",      x = "encoding",      title = paste0("95% sparsity, ", redundancy, "% redundancy")) +    scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0, 0)) +    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1), plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

title: Vectorized Sparse Encoding
text: Test systematically collection diverse integral-valued sparse matrices, including single-cell datasets, movielens datasets, etc.

text: Zach DeBruine. Maintainer.

title: Vectorized Sparse Encodings
text: VSEs vectorized encodings sparse data, intended make two key improvements conventional sparse storage: 1. Efficiently compress redundant discrete integral data far traditional CSC sparse data structures 2. Vectorize sparse data effectively reduce time spent iterating multiple vectors VSEs containers behave like sparse vector classes, offer consistent vocabulary sparse random access iterators make easy develop generic sparse matrix wrapper classes templated containers relying VSEs. project just getting started! learn VSEs, check package vignette! work covered terms GPL-2 v3 license. work independent Sparse Run-length Encoding, non-vectorized form discrete sparse data compression, made available MIT license singlet R package.

title: Benchmark structure performance â benchmark
text: Measure runtime computing column sums sparse-dense matrix multiplication

title: Benchmark structure performance â benchmark
code: benchmark(x, y, n_reps = 100L)

title: Benchmark structure performance â benchmark
text: x sparse matrix object class dgCMatrix dimensions m x n integral non-zero values y dense matrix object class matrix dimensions n x k n_reps number reps

title: Benchmark structure performance â benchmark
text: global variables bench_colsums bench_tcrossprod global environment. Use RcppClock::plot method visualize results, coerce data.frame.

title: Benchmark structure performance â benchmark
code: library(Matrix) x <- rsparsematrix(50, 100, density = 0.5,   rand.x = function(n) { sample(1:10, n, replace = TRUE)}) y <- matrix(runif(10 * 100), 10, 100) VSE::benchmark(x, y) #> constructing CSC #> constructing CSC_P #> constructing CSC_NP #> constructing TCSC_P #> constructing TCSC_NP #> constructing RTCSC_NP plot(bench_tcrossprod)  plot(bench_colsums)

what: Calculate redundancy of data per column â calc_redundancy
title: Calculate redundancy of data per column â calc_redundancy
text: Calculate redundancy data per column

title: Calculate redundancy of data per column â calc_redundancy

code: library(Matrix) A <- rsparsematrix(100, 1000, density = 0.5,   rand.x = function(n) { sample(1:10, n, replace = TRUE)}) v <- colsums(A, encoding = "TRCSC_NP") plot(v, Matrix::colSums(A))

title: Cross-product of transpose â tcrossprod
code: library(Matrix) x <- rsparsematrix(100, 1000, density = 0.5,        rand.x = function(n){sample(1 : 10, n, replace = TRUE)}) y <- matrix(runif(10 * 1000), 10, 1000) plot(VSE::tcrossprod(x, y), t(Matrix::tcrossprod(x, y)))
